Fig. 1 Histograms indicating particle size distribution of Mo on (a) NiMoN/γ-Al2O3, (b) NiMoN/SBA-15 and (c) NiMoN/HMS. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD profiles for the NiMo supported catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XPS spectra for the NiMoO and NiMoN supported on γ-Al2O3. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 NH3-TPD profiles of NiMo supported on γ-Al2O3, SBA-15 and HMS. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Raman spectral mapping of NiMoO/γ-Al2O3 samples. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 FTIR spectra of oleic acid and the hydrodeoxygenated product. Reaction conditions: oleic acid (20 g), n-dodecane (30 g), catalyst loading (2 w/w%), temperature (390 °C), agitation (700 rpm) and initial H2 pressure (6.9 MPa). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Influence of catalyst support on the conversion of oleic acid. Reaction conditions: oleic acid (20 g), n-dodecane (30 g), catalyst loading (2 w/w%), temperature (390 °C), agitation (700 rpm) and initial H2 pressure (6.9 MPa). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Effects of temperature on the conversion of oleic acid. Reaction conditions: oleic acid (20 g), n-dodecane (30 g), catalyst loading (2 w/w%), agitation (700 rpm) and initial H2 pressure (6.9 MPa). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Plot of –ln(1-XA) versus time (min) to calculate the rate constant. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Arrhenius plot for the conversion of oleic acid to n-octadecane using NiMoN/γ-Al2O3. Reaction conditions: oleic acid (20 g), n-dodecane (30 g), catalyst loading (2 w/w%), initial H2 pressure (6.9 MPa), temperature (350–410 °C) and agitation (700 rpm). Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Influence of reaction temperature on conversion and selectivity. Reaction conditions: oleic acid (20 g), n-dodecane (30 g), catalyst (CuNiMo/γ-Al2O3), catalyst loading (2 w/w%), agitation (700 rpm), initial H2 pressure (6.9 MPa) and reaction time (8 h). Fig. 11 Fig. 12 Evaluation of Cu/Fe/Cr supported NiMo/γ-Al2O3 for the HDO of oleic acid. Distinguished Professor and Canada Research Chair Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering University of Saskatchewan 57 Campus Drive Saskatoon Saskatchewan S7N 5A9 Canada Graphical abstract Hydrodeoxygenation of oleic acid was performed using NiMo-based catalyst supported on several mesoporous supports such as γ-Al2O3, SBA-15 and hexagonal mesoporous silica (HMS) in batch mode at 350−410 °C under H2 pressure of 6.9 MPa. The catalysts were synthesized using incipient wet impregnation with approximately 12 wt.% Mo and 4 wt.% Ni loadings. Among the synthesized catalysts, NiMo/SBA-15 demonstrated the highest surface area (484 m2/g) and average pore diameter (9.4 nm). Moreover, γ-Al2O3 showed better catalytic activity during hydrodeoxygenation compared to SBA-15 and HMS supports. At hydrotreating conditions (390 °C and 6.9 MPa), NiMo/γ-Al2O3 showed 77 % oxygen removal and 42 % selectivity towards C16-C18 alkanes during 8 h of batch reaction. To elucidate the promotional effects, bimetallic catalyst (NiMo/γ-Al2O3) promoted with Cu, Cr and Fe (CuNiMo/γ-Al2O3, CrNiMo/γ-Al2O3 and FeNiMo/γ-Al2O3) catalysts were used for hydrodeoxygenation of oleic acid. CuNiMo/γ-Al2O3 gave the highest conversion (ca. 92 %) during hydrodeoxygenation at 300 °C, 6.9 MPa H2 pressure and 600 rpm agitation speed. Keywords Hydrodeoxygenation Oleic acid Green diesel Catalysts Process optimization 1 Introduction The demand for clean and renewable energy sources is accelerating owing to the depleting fossil fuels, global warming and environmental degradation caused by pollution from fossil fuels extraction, processing and utilization [1]. Rapid industrialization, urbanization and motorization are some of the major factors currently shaping our modern energy economy. Higher oxygen content (>35 wt.%) in bio-oils obtained from thermochemical conversion (e.g. pyrolysis and liquefaction) of waste biomass impose certain constraints related to their oxidative instability, reduced calorific value and compromised engine usage due to chances of reactor corrosion [2–4]. To enhance the combustion and storage properties of liquid biofuels including bio-oil and biodiesel, it is essential to remove or reduce the oxygen content. Catalytic hydrotreating of vegetable oils is an upgrading process to produce carbon-neutral green diesel. The upgrading of liquid biofuels through catalytic hydrotreating technologies (e.g., hydrodeoxygenation, hydrodesulfurization, denitrogenation and demetallization) is crucial for the commercial production of usable synthetic transportation fuels [5,6]. Catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is used to remove oxygen and moisture contents from liquid biofuels to enhance their physicochemical and fuel properties [7]. Apart from reducing the levels of oxygenated compounds from bio-oil, HDO is also promising for the production of high-cetane green diesel fuel. Transesterification of vegetable oils is a prominent method to produce bio-based diesel fuel [8]. Several researchers have reported the transesterification of vegetable oils such as canola oil [9,10], palm oil [11], rapeseed oil [12], sunflower oil [13], soybean oil [14], bitter almond oil [15] and Karanja oil [16] as potential feedstocks for biodiesel production. Since most of the vegetable oils are edible, their diversion from human consumption to fuel production has led to the food versus fuel debate. In this regard, waste cooking oil has gained great importance as a feedstock to produce alternate fuels [17–19]. The use of low-value and abundantly available feedstocks are recommended to make the biofuel production process techno-economic feasible [20]. The production of synthetic transportation fuels from biomass-derived liquid oils primarily involves a deoxygenation reaction as a primary step. During direct deoxygenation, hydrogen reacts with the oxygen-rich reactant to produce water as a by-product. Deoxygenation involves the removal of oxygen from the feedstock in the form of CO2 (via decarboxylation) and/or CO (via decarbonylation). The design and development of catalysts with suitable physicochemical properties and reactive performances are some of the most challenging tasks that influence the commercialization of the HDO process [21]. Mostly, noble metals have been employed for hydrotreating bio-oils and vegetable oils. In addition to being expensive, noble metals (e.g., Pd, Pt and Rh) undergo considerable deactivation due to coke formation [22,23]. However, it is reported that noble metal catalyst outperforms traditional hydrotreating catalysts in terms of the yield and degree of deoxygenation. Mesoporous support materials are generally preferred for HDO as they offer the suitable pore diameter required for the diffusion of fatty acid molecules. The porosity and acidity of the catalyst are some of the crucial aspects of the HDO reaction [24]. The acidity of support material influences the magnitude of cracking reactions and product selectivity. The higher the acidity of the support material, the greater is the extent of cracking reaction [25] Single and bimetallic catalysts in reduced phases such as sulfide, carbide, nitride or phosphide are usually used during reactions. The nature of support material can influence the phase alternation in oxide and reduced phase [26]. Highly ordered mesoporous silica supports are widely used for HDO reactions owing to their uniformly distributed pore system, unique structure and physicochemical properties flexible to surface engineering [27,28]. Some studies have focused on the usage of the silica of SBA (Santa Barbara Amorphous) and MCM (Mobil Composition of Matter) in HDO reactions [29–31]. Strongly acidic supports favor uniform dispersion of the active metals while weakly acid supports encounter aggregation of metals into larger particles. The advantage of using SBA-15 and HMA supports is that due to weak acidity, they offer weak metal-support interactions. Ding et al. [32] reported that the reduction of an active metal ion (e.g. Ni2+) was relatively easier in weakly acidic support materials (e.g. activated carbon γ-Al2O3), whereas, in the case of strongly acidic supports (e.g. bentonite, β-zeolite or HZSM-5), the reduction of the active metal was tedious. Vegetable oils such as rapeseed oil and canola oil contain more than 50 wt.% oleic acid as free fatty acid [33]. Therefore, in the present work, mesoporous supported transition metallic (Ni-Mo) nitride catalysts are evaluated for HDO of oleic acid as a model compound of vegetable oils. Supports such as γ-Al2O3, SBA-15 and hexagonal mesoporous silica (HMS) were employed for the synthesis of NiMo catalyst with the evaluation of their catalytic performances for HDO of oleic acid. In our study, SBA-15 and HMS were selected to understand their performances in developing a system of weak acid support material for HDO reactions. Since acid supports favor cracking reactions, an attempt was made to screen the activity of the supports in HDO reactions. The activities of the synthesized catalyst were correlated with their physicochemical characterization. The best performing bimetallic catalyst system was impregnated with promoters such as Cu, Cr and Fe to study the performance of a trimetallic catalytic system. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Chemicals and gases Alumina support (γ-Al2O3) material was purchased from Alfa Aesar Chemicals (Haverhill, MA, USA). Nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate [Ni(NO3)2·6H2O], ammonium heptamolybdate [(NH4)6Mo7O24] and tetraethyl orthosilicate [SiC8H20O4] were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, Oakville, ON, Canada. Copper(II) nitrate trihydrate [Cu(NO3)2·3H2O] and iron(III) chloride (FeCl3) were purchased from VWR (Mississauga, ON, Canada) and Alfa Aesar Chemicals (Haverhill, MA, USA), respectively. All the chemicals had a purity of more than 99 %. Industrial grade hydrogen (>99 %) was purchased from Praxair Canada Inc. (Saskatoon, SK, Canada). 2.2 Catalysts preparation Mesoporous catalyst supports such as SBA-15 and HMS were synthesized using the procedures described by Mouli et al. [34]. SBA-15 was synthesized using Pluronic P123 as the structure-directing agent and tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) as a precursor for silica. The synthesis of SBA-15 is discussed in our previous publications [35,36]. Nickel nitrate and ammonium heptamolybdate served as the precursors for Ni and Mo, respectively. An incipient wetness impregnation method was employed to add the aqueous solution of Ni (4 wt.%) and Mo (12 wt.%) salts onto the support materials (i.e. γ-Al2O3, SBA-15 and HMS). After wet impregnation, the materials were dried at 110 °C for 12 h followed by calcination at 550 °C for 5 h to form an oxide phase of catalysts. The oxide phase of the catalyst was converted to the carbide phase by reduction reaction using a mixture of 10 % ethane, 85 % hydrogen and 5 % nitrogen. The flow rate of the carburizing gas mixture was maintained at a flow rate of 200 mL/min. The carburization temperature (700 °C) and heating rate (1 °C/min) were programmed and controlled using an ATS temperature controller system (Applied Test Systems, Butler, USA). After carburization, passivation was performed using 90 % hydrogen and 10 % nitrogen. Temperature-programmed nitridation was performed in the presence of ammonia (100 %) to obtain the NiMo nitride catalysts designated as NiMoN/γ-Al2O3, NiMoN/SBA-15 and NiMoN/HMS. The nitrided catalyst often tends to be pyrophoric. Hence, they were passivated under a gas mixture of 1 % O2 and 99 % He at 300 °C for 2 h. The catalysts were activated using hydrogen in the reactor before each experiment. For the synthesis of FeCu/γ-Al2O3, iron(III) chloride and copper(II) nitrate trihydrate were used as the precursors for Fe and Cu, respectively. In a typical synthesis procedure, 20 mL of 1 M copper(II) nitrate trihydrate and 30 mL of 1.2 M iron(III) oxide solution were prepared. After impregnation with the copper solution, the support material was dried under room temperature for 12 h followed by calcination at 550 °C for 5 h. After calcination, 20 mL of Iron(III) oxide solution was added to 30 g of catalyst material (Cu/γ-Al2O3). The same drying and calcination procedure was used to obtain FeCu/γ-Al2O3. By theoretical calculations, the synthesized catalyst had Cu and Fe loadings of 13 wt.% and 3 wt.%, respectively. The physicochemical characterization was performed on the synthesized catalysts to understand their structural and chemical properties. 2.3 Catalysts characterization A Micromeritics ASAP 2000 analyzer (Micromeritics Instrument Corp., Norcross, GA, USA) was employed using liquid N2 to measure the surface area and porosity of the synthesized catalysts. To remove the moisture from pores and surface, the catalyst samples were degassed at the temperature of 200 °C at 6.6 × 10−4 Pa. The surface area of the catalysts was measured using a multi-point Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method based on adsorption under the partial pressure P/P0 range from 0.01 to 0.20. CO-chemisorption was measured using the abovementioned Micromeritics ASAP 2020 system. About 0.02 g of catalyst was evacuated under vacuum at 110 °C for 1 h followed by heating to 350 °C under a hydrogen atmosphere at a constant ramp rate of 10 °C/min. The catalyst samples were maintained at 350 °C for 2 h followed by cooling to 35 °C. The coke deposition on the catalysts after each catalytic run was measured using an Elementar Vario EL III CHNOS analyzer (Elementar Analysensysteme, Hanau, Germany). X-ray diffraction (XRD) was employed to evaluate different crystalline and amorphous phases in the synthesized catalysts using a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer (Bruker AXS, Karlsruhe, Germany) equipped with a Bruker Smart 6000 CCD detector and CuK α radiation. Temperature-programmed reaction (TPR) and temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) studies were performed in a TPD/TPR AutosorbiQ Quantachrome instrument (Anton Paar, Montreal, Canada) to understand the extent of acidity of the catalysts. Approximately 100 mg of the catalyst placed in a quartz tube was purged under helium gas at 550 °C for 1 h. After purging, the catalyst was cooled to 40 °C followed by saturation under the flow of a gas mixture (3 vol% NH3 in N2) at 30 mL/min for 2 h [37]. The physically adsorbed NH3 on the catalyst was removed using helium gas for 1 h with an increase in the temperature from 100 °C to 600 °C at constant ramping of 10 °C/min. The TPD signals were recorded using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using soft X-rays from the Variable Line Spacing Plane Grating Monochromator (VLS-PGM) beamline at the Canadian Light Source (CLS) Synchrotron in Saskatoon, Canada. The spectra were collected using a Scienta SES-100 analyzer (VG Scienta, Uppsala, Sweden) in the photoemission mode in the energy range of 5.5−250 eV. Inductive coupled plasma-mass spectroscopy (ICP-MS) was used to obtain the elemental composition of the fresh and regenerated catalysts. Concentrated hydrofluoric acid (50 % v/v) was used to dissolve the catalysts samples (ca. 0.1 g) at 100−150 °C. To ensure the complete dissolution of the metals, concentrated HNO3 was added to the catalyst samples. Using 0.2 N HNO3, the digested samples were analyzed using a PerkinElmer NexION 300D ICP-MS (PerkinElmer, Inc., Waltham, MA, USA). X-ray fluorescence (XRF) analysis was carried out using a Rigaku RIX 3000 WD-XRF system (Applied Rigaku Technologies, Inc., Austin, TX, USA) equipped with a 3 kM generator to analyze the metal loading on the catalyst. A Renishaw InVia Raman microscope was employed for the analysis of the occurrence of hot spots and the distribution of the functional groups on the catalyst surface. The spectra were recorded using Argon laser at 514 nm with a 0.5 cm−1 spatial resolution. The band position, full width at half maximum (FWHM) and intensities were determined using the Lorentz-type deconvolution. Raman spectroscopy is a versatile tool to understand the chemical species distribution on the catalyst surface. The vibrational modes get Raman active if there is an alteration in molecular polarizability. The metal-oxygen and metal-oxygen-metal interactions exhibiting some intense peaks in the Raman shift were studied. 2.4 Hydrodeoxygenation and product characterization 2.4.1 Continuous reactions A high-pressure stainless steel tubular reactor with an inner diameter of 6 mm and a length of 395 mm was employed for continuous hydrotreatment reactions (i.e. temperature: 380 °C, liquid hourly space velocity or LHSV: 0.45 h–1 and H2 pressure: 6.9 MPa) to evaluate the performance of monometallic catalysts systems. The available reaction volume was approximately 10 mL. Liquid reaction samples were pumped up-flow through the reactor for uniform flow distribution and increase the contact time with the catalyst bed. To prevent the solidification of heavier products in the lines, heating tapes controlled by manual rheostats were used. The gas samples were analyzed using an Agilent 7890A gas chromatography (GC) system (Agilent, Santa Clara, CA, USA) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a 30 m long DB-23 column. Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) of the feedstock and products was performed to analyze the organic functional groups using a Spectrum GX system (PerkinElmer, Inc., Waltham, MA, USA) equipped with a deuterated triglycine sulfate (DTGS) detector and a KBr beam splitter. The pre-reduction of catalysts was carried out using 90 % H2 to reduce the catalyst. The liquid samples were also analyzed using the GC system and the oxygen content change was obtained using CHNOS elemental analyzer. The conversion (%) and selectivity (%) were calculated using Eq. (1) and Eq. (2), respectively. (1) C o n v e r s i o n % = C h a n g e i n m o l a r c o n c e n t r a t i o n o f o l e i c a c i d a f t e r r e a c t i o n I n i t i a l m o l a r c o n c e n t r a t i o n o f o l e i c a c i d × 100 (2) S e l e c t i v i t y % = M o l a r c o n c e n t r a t i o n o f e a c h p r o d u c t M o l a r c o n c e n t r a t i o n o f o l e i c a c i d c o n v e r t e d t o p r o d u c t s × 100 2.4.2 Batch reactions The HDO reactions were performed in a batch setup using a 300 mL Parr reactor consisting of a four-bladed impeller for agitation. For each catalytic run, 20 g of the feedstock (oleic acid) and 30 g of solvent (dodecane) were used along with 2 wt.% (of total feed) loading of the nitride catalyst. After loading the calculated quantities of the feedstock and solvent, the autoclave was flushed with nitrogen gas and pressurized using hydrogen to obtain the desired reaction pressure. The reactor was agitated at 700 rpm for 8 h under an H2 partial pressure of 6.5 MPa. All the experiments were conducted in triplicate with a standard error of less than 3 %. Sample derivatization was performed for methyl ester of fatty acids and n-alkane/α-olefin using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC/MS) analysis. Using boron trifluoride-methanol (1 mL, 14 % w/w), 1 mL of methanol and toluene, an aliquot of the sample was prepared. Deuterated hexadecenoic acid and hexacosane were used as derivatization surrogates for the acids and n-alkane/α-olefin, respectively. The GC–MS analysis was performed on Agilent 6890 (Agilent, Santa Clara, CA, USA) using the Supelco SP-23080 column. For the n-alkane/α-olefin analysis, the DB-5 ms column was employed. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Evaluation of monometallic catalysts in continuous setup The comparison of physicochemical properties of molybdenum (Mo), vanadium (V) and tungsten (W) supported on γ-Al2O3 in carbide and nitride phase is shown in Table 1 . The metal loading of Mo, W and V were 7.4, 10 and 3.1 wt.% respectively to ensure equal availability of active sites for all the catalysts [38]. In the continuous setup, the catalyst loadings (MoN/γ-Al2O3: 2 g; WN/γ-Al2O3: 1.42 g; VN/γ-Al2O3: 1.26 g; MoC/γ-Al2O3: 2 g; WC/γ-Al2O3: 1.42 g; VC/γ-Al2O3: 1.26 g) were modified to ensure availability of the same number of active sites for all the catalysts (Table 2 ). In our screening tests, the performance of Mo was observed to be better than W and V in terms of catalytic activity (Table 3 ). As reported by Duan et al. [39], higher loading of molybdenum can cause a decrease in catalytic activity due to the preferential occupation of molybdenum species over anionic vacancy sites and increased coverage of nickel active sites. An increase in molybdenum loading from 1 wt.% to 15 wt.% on Ni/ZrO2 catalyst, substantially decreased the catalytic activity and selectivity. At an optimized metal (Mo) loading of 10 wt.%, the catalytic conversion and selectivity were reported to be maximum (>75 %). In commercial hydrotreating catalysts, the molybdenum loading is usually around 13 wt.%. At a steady-state condition, the HDO conversion in the continuous system was approximately 96 %. At the same reaction conditions, a single metallic catalyst (MoN/γ-Al2O3) gave a conversion of 87 % in continuous and batch modes, the conversion was 65 %. 3.2 Evaluation of NiMo supported on γ-Al2O3, SBA-15 and HMS 3.2.1 Characterization of catalysts The physicochemical properties of the transition bimetallic catalysts such as surface area and pore volume are presented in Table 4 . It could be seen that NiMo/SBA-15 catalyst had a higher surface area (484 m2/g) in comparison to the other two catalysts. The incorporation of active metals onto the support material was found to reduce the surface area, pore volume and pore diameter. The γ-Al2O3 support demonstrated the BET surface area, pore volume and pore diameter of 235 m2/g, 0.69 cm3/g and 13.1 nm, respectively, which were reduced to 205 m2/g, 0.48 cm3/g and 10.2 nm, respectively after the impregnation of the active metals. The catalyst with a high pore diameter (>10 nm) helps in the movement of bulky molecules such as oleic acid through its pores, thereby offering more active sites for the adsorption of the reactants while increasing the reaction rate. Hence, it was anticipated that γ-Al2O3 support could offer a better catalytic activity for the HDO of oleic acid. The histogram analysis (Fig. 1 ) of NiMoN supported on γ-Al2O3 and SBA-15 was performed to determine the particle size distribution. The formation of 8 nm slabs is dominant for NiMo supported on γ-Al2O3 in comparison to its counterparts. Therefore, it can be inferred that the higher activity of NiMoN/γ-Al2O3 for the HDO of oleic acid is due to the formation of layered Mo2N slabs in the nitride phase of the catalyst. From the XRD analysis, it was observed that NiMo/γ-Al2O3 exhibited a strong 2θ peak at 43° and 63° (Fig. 2 ). These peaks are attributed to the formation of crystalline NiO species. In the case of NiMo supported on HMS, zeolites, ZrO2 and SBA-15, the 2θ peaks at 43° and 63° were not observed, which indicates the absence of the crystalline phase of the metals on the support material. Based on reference data (JCPDS 00-004-0875), the 2θ diffraction peaks at 62.2°, 42.4° and 36° are assigned to the crystalline phase of γ-Al2O3. The XPS studies were carried out to examine the oxidation states of the nickel and molybdenum species and elucidate the metal-support interactions (Fig. 3 ). From these spectra, it was concluded that nitriding the catalyst resulted in increased availability of the surface nickel species. In comparison to the Al (2p) peak for oxide and nitride samples, it can be observed that in the nitride phase of the catalyst, the Al (2p) peak shifted to lower energy (73 eV) as opposed to the oxide phase (78 eV). Additionally, the highly intense Mo (4 s) peak of molybdenum is not evident for the nitride phase of the catalyst. The absence of Mo (4 s) peak on the catalyst surface indicates that molybdenum atoms form strong chemical bonds with the support material and nickel subsequently bonds with molybdenum forming the desired NiMoN species. From the NH3-TPD results (Fig. 4 ), it can be seen moderate acidity of the alumina support material is expected to be beneficial for HDO as it aids the cracking reaction. In summary, nitriding the catalyst can lead to the increased availability of the promoter species on the surface of the catalyst. Raman spectroscopy indicates the non-uniform distribution of the metal species on the support material (Fig. 5 ). The Mo7O24 6− exhibits a strong peak at 940 cm−1 and the formation of a reduced Mo phase is attributed to the peaks around 380 and 400 cm−1. The formation of nickel aluminate (NiAl2O4) species is indicative of promoter-support interactions, which promotes catalyst deactivation. The occurrence of MoO4 2− species is confirmed using the bands at 890, 312 and 300 cm−1. Polymolybdate species were confirmed by the Raman shifts at 950 cm-1 and 825 cm−1. Two peaks at 955 and 965 cm-1 were characteristic of nickel molybdate (NiMo4) species. Besides, the band at 995 cm-1 corresponds to the MoO stretching mode. Based on the Raman spectroscopy, it is evident that most of the dispersed molybdenum ions are present as polyanions ([Mo7O24]6− or [Mo8O26]4−) determined from the bands at 975 and 993 cm−1. Based on the comparison of Raman spectra for the core and border regions of a specific catalyst extrudate, patterned distribution of molybdenum (hot spots) were observed. It also indicates that active metals (Mo and Ni) are not uniformly distributed on the support material and there is a pattern governing the migration of the active metal species. 3.2.2 Effects of process parameters on hydrodeoxygenation reaction The samples collected after the HDO reaction for 8 h at 390 °C under H2 partial pressure of 6.9 MPa using NiMoN/γ-Al2O3 catalyst were analyzed using FTIR spectroscopy to determine the presence of functional groups in feedstock and product sample (Fig. 6 ). The band at 1712 cm−1 is characteristic of the CO stretching (carbonyl group) in oleic acid and the band at 1466 cm−1 is attributed to the COO asymmetric stretching [40]. Both these bands were almost absent in the product indicating that the catalyst was efficient to cause hydrogenolysis of the CO bond followed by deoxygenation. No stretching at 1286 cm−1 was observed indicating the absence of CO stretching attributed to aldehydes and ketones [41]. The broad stretching between 3500 and 2500 cm−1 was due to the OH stretching band, which exists in dimeric form due to the hydrogen bonding [31]. The stretching vibrations owing to CH2 and CH3 groups were detected between 2800 and 2950 cm−1. Commercial γ-Al2O3 had higher acidity than SBA-15 and HMS as confirmed by using the NH3-TPD measurements. Several catalytic HDO reactions were carried out using different supports (γ-Al2O3, SBA-15 and HMS) to further understand the influence of acidity of the support on the reaction. Fig. 7 shows the influence of the support materials on the HDO of oleic acid at 390 °C, H2 pressure of 6.5 MPa and at 700 rpm. Over the reaction time of 8 h, γ-Al2O3 gave a better conversion (∼45 %) in comparison to other support materials (35–40 %). The supporting acidity has a substantial influence on the HDO reaction. During the HDO reaction, the acidity of support material is a significant factor. From the NH3-TPD analysis, it was found that the acidity of γ-Al2O3 was higher than SBA-15 and HMS. Fig. 8 indicates the influence of the temperature on the HDO of oleic acid using NiMoN/γ-Al2O3. From the different temperatures studied (350-410 °C), it was observed that temperature has a noteworthy effect on oleic acid conversion. At a reaction time of 8 h, the conversion increased from 65 % to 78 % with the rise in temperature from 350 to 410 °C. During the reaction time of 8 h, the conversion reached a maximum of 80 % on the molar basis after which no significant change in the conversion was observed at longer reaction times (>8 h). The regeneration of the catalyst was performed by washing the spent catalyst using methanol and drying it at 110 °C for 24 h followed by calcination at 550 °C for 6 h. Carbon deposition on the Al2O3-supported metal catalyst was relatively less than SBA-15 and HMS (Table 5 ). Regeneration of the catalyst was performed by washing the spent catalyst using methanol followed by drying at 110 °C for 24 h and calcining at 550 °C for 6 h. Elemental composition analysis using ICP-MS indicates a substantial difference in the active metal content of fresh and regenerated catalysts (Table 6 ). 3.2.3 Kinetics of hydrodeoxygenation of oleic acid Kumar et al. [25] proposed an empirical kinetic model for the HDO of stearic acid using the Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. The elimination of external mass transfer resistance and internal diffusional resistance are some important factors for the kinetic studies of a chemical reaction. As stated earlier, the agitation speed had a negligible influence on the oleic acid conversion. Table 7 indicates the influence of agitation speed on the extent of HDO using the NiMoN/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. It could be concluded that the speed of agitation does not have a major influence on the HDO reaction. Since no major difference in conversion was observed as the agitation speed increased from 500 to 1100 rpm, the reaction was carried out at 700 rpm. Therefore, the reaction was assumed free from external mass transfer resistance. During the development of the model, the concentration of hydrogen was not considered as it was used in excess with the assumption of the reaction being first-order concerning the liquid components in the reaction. Fig. 9 indicates the kinetic plot to get the rate of constant values for the reaction. The second-order polynomial function was employed to fit the plot, and at all temperatures, the R2 was 0.99. The Arrhenius plot [ln(k) versus 1/T] helped determine the pre-exponential factors and activation energy through the rate constant (k) values. The activation energy during the HDO of oleic acid to octadecane was determined to be 37 kJ/mol (Fig. 10 ). Ayodele et al. [42] studied the kinetics for HDO of oleic acid using zeolite-supported fluoro molybdenum oxalate catalyst. The energy required for the hydrogenation of oleic acid to stearic acid was 98.7 kJ/mol and the hydrodeoxygenation of stearic acid was 130.3 kJ/mol at a reaction temperature of 360 °C and pressure of 2 MPa. The promotional effects of nickel were attributed to the activation energy of 37 kJ/mol similar to our observations. 3.3 Screening tests in batch mode for the trimetallic catalyst system 3.3.1 Experimental runs In a batch system, a maximum conversion of 80 % was achieved over a reaction time of 8 h. Fig. 11 indicates the temperature dependence of the conversion of oleic acid and selectivity towards n-octadecane using the CuNiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Higher temperatures (> 300 °C) are usually required for the splitting of the gaseous hydrogen molecule and further spillover of hydrogen species on the active metal sites [21]. The presence of nickel promotes the migration of hydrogen species (spillover), whereas the reduced sites on molybdenum metal promote sites for the adsorption of oxygen-containing molecules [21,38]. An increase in the temperature from 260 °C to 320 °C under a hydrogen pressure of 6.9 MPa and a reaction time of 8 h in batch setup caused an increase in oleic acid conversion from 75 % to 92 %. However, the selectivity towards n-octadecane was found to decrease as the reaction temperature reached 300 °C. Cracking reactions are favored at higher temperatures (>300 °C) resulting in the formation of other products [21]. During the hydrogenation reaction, n-dodecane was the major product formed for reaction temperatures above 300 °C indicating that cracking reactions are favored resulting in the formation of products with decreased carbon numbers. Fig. 12 shows the comparison between the performances of trimetallic catalysts containing 6 wt.% of secondary promoters at different reaction times. Metals such as Cu, Fe and Cr were selected because they tend to have a high affinity towards oxygen and offer unsaturated vacancy sites for oxygen adsorption. The performance of trimetallic catalysts systems did not follow any particular pattern. However, the impregnation of copper was found to be beneficial in comparison to other metals (i.e. Fe and Cr). 3.3.2 Process optimization study The fluctuations in the reaction temperature have the most significant influence on oleic acid conversion and product selectivity. However, cracking reactions occur at a temperature above 325 °C and thus selectivity towards n-octadecane was found to decrease. Hence, using higher reaction temperatures (> 300 °C) for HDO of oleic acid was not preferable. Higher catalyst loading (6 wt.%) aids in the oleic acid conversion and selectivity towards n-octadecane. Therefore, an increase in the catalyst loading to 8 wt.% is also beneficial. However, considering the cost involved and environmental aspects of using higher catalysts loading at an industrial scale processing, we choose to perform reactions with a catalyst loading of 6 wt.%. Hydrogen pressure plays a major role in aiding hydrogenation and deoxygenation reaction. A higher H2 pressure of 6.9 MPa favors the spillover of H2 aiding the hydrogenation and deoxygenation reactions [7]. Furthermore, reaction time had a significant influence on oleic acid conversion and selectivity towards n-octadecane. From the observations achieved from orthogonal experiments and range analysis, the optimal level for each parameter was reaction temperature (300 °C), reaction time (8 h), catalyst loading (8 wt.%) and H2 pressure (6.9 MPa). 3.4 Hydrodeoxygenation modeling using novel FeCu/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in batch mode The synthesized FeCu/γ-Al2O3 catalyst had a metal dispersion of 8.1 % (i.e. metallic surface area: 2.12 m2/g, crystallite size: 15.4 nm and CO adsorption: 29.7 μmol/g). No major changes in the surface areas between the reduced and the used catalyst were observed. For example, the BET surface area of reduced, used and regenerated FeCu/γ-Al2O3 catalysts was 220.1 m2/g, 217.1 m2/g and 205.1 m2/g, respectively. The decrease in the surface area in the case of FeCu/γ-Al2O3 was only 6 %. These results indicate that the usage of support materials is beneficial for HDO reactions. Therefore, the prolonged usage of unsupported catalysts may not be economically beneficial because of the rapid lowering of the surface area. 4 Conclusions NiMoN/Al2O3 catalyst had a higher pore diameter (10.2 nm) in comparison to other catalysts that were evaluated. The evaluation results indicated that γ-Al2O3 support material performed well in terms of selectivity towards C18 paraffin such as n-octadecane (ca. 40 %). Higher temperatures (>390 °C) favored cracking reactions causing a decrease in the selectivity towards n-octadecane. The order of performance based on oleic acid conversion and selectivity towards n-octadecane was as follows: γ-Al2O3 > SBA-15 > HMS. The acidity of the support material plays a vital role in the HDO reaction. It can be stated that the higher the acidity, the higher is the activity of the catalyst towards HDO reaction. From the pseudo-first-order kinetic analysis, it was found that the apparent activation energy for the HDO of oleic acid to n-octadecane was 37 kJ/mol. Based on the evaluation of trimetallic catalyst systems, a novel FeCu/γ-Al2O3 was developed and HDO using FeCu/γ-Al2O3 as the catalyst was optimized in a batch reactor. coredata.dc:description: Hydrodeoxygenation of oleic acid was performed using NiMo-based catalyst supported on several mesoporous supports such as γ-Al2O3, SBA-15 and hexagonal mesoporous silica (HMS) in batch mode at 350−410 °C under H2 pressure of 6.9 MPa. The catalysts were synthesized using incipient wet impregnation with approximately 12 wt.% Mo and 4 wt.% Ni loadings. Among the synthesized catalysts, NiMo/SBA-15 demonstrated the highest surface area (484 m2/g) and average pore diameter (9.4 nm). Moreover, γ-Al2O3 showed better catalytic activity during hydrodeoxygenation compared to SBA-15 and HMS supports. At hydrotreating conditions (390 °C and 6.9 MPa), NiMo/γ-Al2O3 showed 77 % oxygen removal and 42 % selectivity towards C16-C18 alkanes during 8 h of batch reaction. To elucidate the promotional effects, bimetallic catalyst (NiMo/γ-Al2O3) promoted with Cu, Cr and Fe (CuNiMo/γ-Al2O3, CrNiMo/γ-Al2O3 and FeNiMo/γ-Al2O3) catalysts were used for hydrodeoxygenation of oleic acid. CuNiMo/γ-Al2O3 gave the highest conversion (ca. 92 %) during hydrodeoxygenation at 300 °C, 6.9 MPa H2 pressure and 600 rpm agitation speed.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrodeoxygenation of oleic acid using γ-Al2O3 supported transition metallic catalyst systems: Insight into the development of novel FeCu/γ-Al2O3 catalyst
